activities.description: [DECISION] Experiment result: Qwen boardroom as adversarial reviewer for Claude audit
activities.details: Ran 4 Claude subagents (UI/UX, Architecture, Cognitive, Value/ROI) for deep audit, then 4 Qwen agents (Devil's Advocate, Pragmatist, Minimalist, Builder) to challenge findings. Results: (1) Did Qwen find anything Claude didn't? NO. No new bugs or issues surfaced. Devil's Advocate's "state.json is a fail-safe" claim was wrong -- it's genuinely a dead file read. (2) Did Qwen change priority ordering? PARTIALLY. Pragmatist's "comment-out don't delete" for brain engines is a reasonable middle ground Claude didn't propose. Builder pushed for "verify before purge" which is cautious but valid. (3) Was 160-char limit too constraining? YES. Arguments were surface-level. Devil's Advocate kept repeating "resilience" and "fallback" without substantiation. No agent could cite code or provide evidence. (4) Groupthink check: Devil's Advocate was contrarian but shallow -- kept asserting things are "fallbacks" with no evidence. Pragmatist and Builder converged quickly. Minimalist was the strongest voice. VERDICT: Qwen boardroom adds marginal value for audit review. Better suited for brainstorming/ideation than code-level analysis. The 160-char limit kills depth. For future audits, skip the boardroom step.

Full designs saved at .hello-world/shared-files/boardroom-v2-thinktank.md (75KB). Core proposals to implement: (1) callQwenPanel() -- parallel Qwen calls with file injection, no char limit, merged output. (2) Later: add priming phase, structured positions, challenge rounds, repetition detection via Jaccard similarity, mediator synthesis.

activities.description:
Boardroom: CONTEXT: You are senior developers on the Hello World project -- an autonomous AI workspace where Claude operates as the primary developer. The brain memory system is the core differentiator: tiered memory (pain/win/fact/decision/architecture), quality gate scoring, cortex learning, pruning, and reflection.

FILES YOU BUILT:
- scoring.ts: decay rates per type, severity multipliers, access boost, failure penalties, supersededBy handling, contradiction detection via tag overlap
- pruner.ts: archives memories below minScore or past maxStaleDays, physically removes from active pool
- cortex-learner.ts: learns word->tag mappings from retrieval gaps, substring matching, 2-observation minimum, no unlearn path
- reflection.ts: generates predictions, compares to outcomes, stores "Surprise" memories as new records linked to originals

EXTERNAL AUDIT FINDINGS (from 4 independent Qwen analysts):

1. RECONSOLIDATION MISSING (all 4 agreed): Memories are immutable after creation. When retrieved, content never updates -- only accessCount/lastAccessed change. Reflections create NEW memories instead of updating originals. This causes fragmentation: "correction chains" instead of refined knowledge.

2. SAFETY ATROPHY: Pain memories decay (half-life 28 days) and get pruned when score drops below threshold. The knowledge that prevents failures gets deleted for being "stale" -- guaranteeing recurrence of past catastrophes.

3. CORTEX POISONING: cortex-learner uses substring matching (string.includes) with only 2 observations needed. Wrong associations get baked in at 0.95 confidence with no negative feedback or unlearn path. Creates epistemic echo chambers.

4. CONTRADICTION DETECTION BRITTLE: findContradictions requires minTagOverlap=2 and exact type match. Two conflicting facts with different tags coexist without detection. "Use V1" and "Use V2" both survive if tagged differently.

5. QUALITY GATE REWARDS VERBOSITY: computeQualityScore gives +0.2 for detailLength > 200. Incentivizes padding over precision. Short sharp rules score lower than verbose fluff.

6. ARCHIVE IS AMNESIA: pruner physically removes memories. Archived memories can't influence behavior (no priming). Biological forgetting is retrieval failure, not deletion.

7. NO CONTEXTUAL RETRIEVAL: scoring is global (time + access frequency), not query-dependent. A 2-year-old architecture memory scores low even when the current query is exactly about that architecture.

8. REFLECTION RECURSION RISK: No maxReflectionDepth or cooldown. Reflections on reflections could create storms.

DISCUSS: Which findings are actionable now vs theoretical? What's the implementation priority? What can we fix without breaking the system? Are any findings wrong or misunderstanding our constraints (single-user JSON file system, not distributed)?

Panel: STRUCTURED DELIBERATION -- ROUND 2: ADDRESS EACH OTHER'S OPINIONS

You are continuing a structured debate about the Hello World brain memory system audit findings. In Round 1, three experts stated their positions. Now you must:

1. Read all three Round 1 opinions below
2. Address each of the other two experts' positions -- where you agree, where you disagree, and why
3. Form your UPDATED opinion based on hearing the others
4. Vote: CONCLUDE (we have enough consensus to act) or CONTINUE (need more discussion)

---
ROUND 1 OPINIONS:

**NOVA (Brain Architect):**
- Finding 1 (Reconsolidation): PARTIALLY AGREE -- immutability was intentional for JSON safety, but correction chains bloat the active set
- Finding 2 (Safety Atrophy): AGREE -- uniform decay rates cause safety constraints to expire
- Finding 3 (Cortex Poisoning): AGREE -- v1 substring matching too naive, no negative reinforcement
- Finding 4 (Contradiction Detection): DISAGREE -- semantic detection is over-engineering for <500 memories
- Finding 5 (Verbosity): AGREE -- detailLength > 200 is a flawed metric
- Finding 6 (Archive Amnesia): PARTIALLY AGREE -- archive exists but retrieval never queries it
- Finding 7 (Contextual Retrieval): AGREE -- global scoring reduces precision
- Finding 8 (Reflection Recursion): AGREE -- needs maxReflectionDepth
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy fix (tag-based decay exemption), Contextual Retrieval (query-dependent scoring), Cortex Poisoning (raise to 3 obs + negative feedback)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 4 -- contradiction detection is fine for our scale

**FORGE (Systems Engineer):**
- Finding 1: PARTIALLY AGREE -- immutability safer for JSON, need better supersededBy handling
- Finding 2: AGREE -- exempt safety-tagged memories from pruning
- Finding 3: AGREE -- 0.95 confidence on 2 observations is statistically unsound
- Finding 4: DISAGREE -- fuzzy matching adds complexity and false positives at our scale
- Finding 5: AGREE -- remove detailLength bonus immediately
- Finding 6: AGREE -- archive exists but retrieval ignores it
- Finding 7: PARTIALLY AGREE -- tag-match boost yes, semantic scoring is YAGNI
- Finding 8: AGREE -- needs MAX_REFLECTION_DEPTH = 3
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy (exempt from pruning), Reflection Recursion guard (crash risk), Quality Gate fix (remove verbosity bonus)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 4 -- exact matching is deterministic and debuggable

**SAGE (Product Strategist):**
- Finding 1: AGREE -- immutable corrections create conflicting truth states
- Finding 2: AGREE -- deleting pain signals destroys user trust
- Finding 3: AGREE -- confidently wrong is worse than unsure
- Finding 4: AGREE -- brittle tag matching lets semantic contradictions through
- Finding 5: AGREE -- degrades signal-to-noise ratio
- Finding 6: PARTIALLY AGREE -- pruning needed for performance, but need cold-storage retrieval
- Finding 7: AGREE -- global scoring fails to surface relevant context
- Finding 8: AGREE -- crash risk for single-threaded app
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy (add decay_exempt flag + UI lock icon), Contextual Retrieval (TF-IDF or embedding similarity), Cortex Poisoning (probationary period + unlearn path)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 6 -- pruning is a feature, amnesia is a retrieval bug

activities.details:
Quality: 4 tension, 2 shifted, 1 consensus
  1. [TENSION] Finding 1 (Safety Atrophy): Should pain memories be exempt from decay and pruning? What's the right mechanism -- a decay_exempt flag, a minimum floor on synapticStrength, or something else? -> decay_exempt for pain+high-severity only. Pragmatist scoped it to limit immortal pool. Contrarian raised valid accumulation concern, addressed by severity gate.
  2. [TENSION] Finding 2 (Reflection Recursion): Should we cap reflection depth at MAX_REFLECTION_DEPTH=3? Is recursion actually happening in practice, or is this a theoretical concern? -> Simple filter: exclude reflection-type from meta-observation input (3 LOC). First Principles reframed as design boundary.
  3. [SHIFTED] Finding 3 (Cortex Poisoning): Should we raise the cortex observation threshold from 2 to 3 and add negative feedback? What's the risk of making the cortex too conservative? -> Threshold 2->3 plus per-session observation dedup. First Principles shifted focus to observation quality over count.
  4. [CONSENSUS] Finding 4 (Verbosity Bonus): Should we remove the detailLength>200 = +0.2 scoring bonus? Does longer content actually correlate with lower quality in our system? -> Unanimous: replace verbosity bonus with rule-presence check.
  5. [SHIFTED] Finding 5 (Contextual Retrieval): Should we add tag-boosting at query time? How would this interact with the existing synapticStrength-based ranking? -> Tag-boosting in rankMemories, overlap*0.1 capped at 0.3. Contrarian shifted design with the cap.
  6. [TENSION] Finding 6 (Archive Retrieval): Should we query the archive on cache miss? What's the performance cost and what defines a 'cache miss' in our retrieval pipeline? -> DEFERRED until archive is populated. First Principles distinguished stale vs superseded for future implementation.
  7. [TENSION] Implementation priority: Of the approved changes, what's the optimal build order considering dependencies and risk? -> 3 batches: Batch 1 (F4+F2+F3-threshold, one commit). activities.details:
Brain Memory Audit: 5 of 6 findings approved, 1 deferred. Implementation in 3 batches.

BATCH 1 (quick wins, one commit, ~9 LOC):
- F4: Replace verbosity bonus with rule-presence check in reflection.ts computeQualityScore()
- F2: Filter reflection-type memories from generateMetaObservations() input
- F3a: Raise cortex minObservations default from 2 to 3

BATCH 2 (types change, ~15 LOC):
- F1: Add decayExempt field to Memory type. Auto-set true for pain+high-severity. scoreMemory() skips decay when true. Pruner skips archive for exempt memories.

BATCH 3 (retrieval path, ~25 LOC, needs test pass):
- F5: Add queryTags param to rankMemories(). Tag overlap * 0.1, capped at 0.3 total boost. Thread cortex-resolved tags through retrieval caller.
- F3b: Deduplicate cortex gap observations per session (max 1 observation per word per session)

DEFERRED:
- F6: Archive retrieval -- revisit when archive is populated with real data. When implemented: only serve stale-archived, never superseded.

KEY DESIGN DECISIONS FROM DELIBERATION:
- Contrarian's cap on F5 (0.3 max) prevents tag-boost from dominating decay scores
- First Principles' session dedup on F3 addresses observation quality, not just quantity
- Pragmatist's severity gate on F1 limits immortal memory pool to ~10-20 entries
- Architect's batching groups changes by blast radius for safer shipping

activities.description:
Panel: JUDGE PANEL: Review and rank every multi-agent collaboration method tested in the Hello World project. You are judges evaluating which methods produce the best outcomes.

## THE EXPERIMENTS (chronological)

### Method 1: Deliberation System v1 (Feb 23-24)
- Platform: Claude MCP tools (hw_start_deliberation, hw_post_agent_message)
- Agents: 4 cognitive lenses (contrarian, premortem, firstprinciples, steelman) -- all voiced by Claude
- Format: Claude reads last 6 messages, decides who speaks next, voices each agent. 670-char limit per message.
- Mediator: Claude acts as "Reason" -- frames questions, synthesizes, pushes back
- Guardrails: sub-questions tracked, coverage checks, quality tags (consensus/tension/shifted)
- OUTCOME: Ran ~17 deliberation sessions. Early ones had groupthink (agents lumped and dismissed topics). After guardrails added: produced real tension, caught design flaws, led to actionable decisions. One deliberation audited its own guardrails and found 5 structural failures.
- PAIN: Mediator let lazy consensus ride. Agents dismissed topics without engaging. Coverage checks were stale.
- WIN: After fixes, produced binding decisions that shipped. Today's brain audit deliberation had 4 tension, 2 shifted, 1 consensus -- healthy quality.

### Method 2: Qwen Boardroom v1 (Feb 27)
- Platform: hw_run_boardroom (Qwen agents via API, sequential chat)
- Agents: 3-4 Qwen agents with fixed roles, 300-char message limit, 8 rounds round-robin
- Format: Each agent gets last N messages, posts a response. Whiteboard available but underused.
- OUTCOME: Shallow consensus. Agents agreed too quickly, repeated each other, didn't use whiteboard. 6 concrete quality problems identified: (1) premature convergence, (2) 300-char too short for substance, (3) whiteboard unused, (4) no file access, (5) no evidence grounding, (6) repetitive dialogue.
- PAIN: When Claude agents were put in the boardroom, 2/3 timed out (30s limit too short). 300-char limit doesn't suit Claude's longer responses.

### Method 3: Parallel Research Sprints (Feb 25-26)
- Platform: Task tool with multiple agents in parallel
- Agents: 6 Sonnet agents, each researching a different angle (competitors, academia, practitioners, simple baselines, anti-patterns, synthesis)
- Format: Independent parallel execution, no inter-agent communication. Each agent returns results. Claude synthesizes.
- OUTCOME: 6 research tasks in 3 minutes. Covered memory systems, Qwen evaluation, competitor analysis comprehensively. 
- PAIN: Results exist only in conversation context -- vanish on session end. Some redundancy between agents. Shallow when prompts are too open-ended.
- WIN: Best for information gathering. Fast, cheap, comprehensive coverage.

### Method 4: Parallel Agent Worktrees for Code (Feb 26-27)
- Platform: Task tool with isolation=worktree
- Agents: 3-4 agents each in isolated git worktree, writing code to different files
- Format: Each agent gets specific file assignments and specs. No inter-agent communication. Merge manually.
- OUTCOME: Brain Magnum Opus S48: 4-agent parallel build shipped entire foundation (~800 lines). Today: 3 teams built all 3 brain audit batches simultaneously (~49 LOC across 7 files). All builds pass.
- PAIN: If two agents touch the same file, merge conflicts. Agents sometimes go beyond spec (extra refactoring).
- WIN: Massive time savings for non-overlapping code changes. Today's 3 batches would have taken 3x longer sequentially.

### Method 5: Qwen Panel (Parallel Independent Analysis) (Feb 27)
- Platform: hw_qwen_panel (parallel Qwen agents, no char limit, file injection)
- Agents: 4 Qwen agents with file injection, each produces independent analysis
- Format: Each agent gets the full topic + injected files, writes a complete analysis independently. No inter-agent communication. Results saved to .hello-world/panels/.
- OUTCOME: 4 agents, 4 files injected, 50K tokens in 93 seconds. Agents CAN see files. Comprehensive independent analyses.
- PAIN: No interaction means no debate, no tension, no position shifts. Just 4 parallel essays.
- WIN: Cheap (Qwen pricing), fast, good for gathering diverse perspectives on the same material.

### Method 6: Structured Multi-Round Qwen Panel (Feb 27)
- Platform: Sequential hw_qwen_panel calls with opinion tracking
- Agents: 3 Qwen agents, 2 rounds
- Format: Round 1: agents independently form opinions (AGREE/PARTIALLY/DISAGREE on findings + TOP 3 priorities). Round 2: feed all Round 1 opinions back, agents address each other, shift positions, vote CONCLUDE/CONTINUE.
- OUTCOME: Produced clear consensus map with tracked position shifts. ~25K tokens across 2 rounds. More effective than boardroom chat.
- WIN: Explicit opinion tracking makes shifts visible. Cheap. Actually produces debate in round 2.
- PAIN: Still Qwen-quality reasoning (not as deep as Claude). 2 rounds may not be enough for complex topics.

### Method 7: 7-Agent Think Tank (Boardroom v2 Design) (Feb 27)
- Platform: hw_qwen_panel with 5 Qwen + 2 Claude agents
- Agents: 7 agents each writing a complete design document (protocol designer, anti-groupthink specialist, file access architect, etc.)
- Format: Each agent produced a multi-page design doc independently. No interaction.
- OUTCOME: 87KB of design proposals. Comprehensive coverage. The documents became reference material for future boardroom redesign.
- PAIN: No actual debate between the 7 agents. Just 7 parallel essays. Massive output to synthesize manually.

### Method 8: Today's Full Pipeline (Feb 27)
- Deliberation (4 Claude-voiced agents) -> Coverage check -> Conclude -> Extract recommendations -> 3 parallel worktree teams build simultaneously
- OUTCOME: Best end-to-end result yet. Deliberation had real tension (4/7 questions). Agents shifted positions on 2 questions. Then 3 parallel teams built all approved changes in one shot. Total: ~49 LOC committed, 0 errors.

## YOUR TASK
For each method, score on these dimensions (1-10):
1. DEPTH OF REASONING -- did agents produce genuinely new insights?
2. CONSTRUCTIVE TENSION -- did real disagreement surface and get resolved?
3. ACTIONABILITY -- did the output lead to concrete, shippable changes?
4. EFFICIENCY -- cost, time, token usage relative to output quality
5. SCALABILITY -- can this method handle bigger/harder problems?

Then rank all 8 methods overall and explain your ranking. What's the best method for what use case?

activities.description: Decision: Multi-project: hub model, not project-scoped switching
activities.details:
Chosen: Hub model: one brain, one memory pool, no project switching. Tasks/memories get a project tag for filtering, not scoping. App respects launch directory (CWD bug) but doesn't partition state. The MP epic's 4 sub-tasks are replaced by a simple tag+filter approach.
Simpler architecture, preserves cross-project learning, matches how IDEs work. Scoping memories per project would fragment the brain's most valuable asset: lessons that transfer across codebases. The project switcher UX was solving a problem that doesn't exist if there's nothing to switch.

All 5 sub-questions addressed
activities.details:
Quality: 1 tension, 2 shifted, 2 consensus
  1. [CONSENSUS] What sources should be scanned and what content is actually valuable enough to store? -> Tight deps-only list: package.json dependencies (Tauri, React, Biome), Anthropic changelog, Claude Code changelog. No blogs, no broad AI news, no research papers.
  2. [SHIFTED] What cadence makes sense -- scheduled (cron/daily/weekly), event-driven (on session start), or on-demand only? -> Manual /scan trial first (2-4 weeks), then weekly Task Scheduler if 3+ useful memories stored. Product Mgr and Backend Arch both shifted from session-start to manual-first. Pragmatist shifted from pure on-demand to accepting automation post-trial.
  3. [TENSION] How should intake be triggered technically -- Windows Task Scheduler, hook-based, app-based, or external service? -> Phase 1: manual /scan command writes to knowledge-queue.json staging file. Phase 2: weekly Windows Task Scheduler (like SyncClaudeUsage) runs zero-LLM Node script. Session-start hook drains the queue. DevOps wanted daily, group voted weekly.
  4. [CONSENSUS] How do we prevent memory bloat -- what filtering, deduplication, and quality gates should intake pass through? -> Zero-LLM scan (HTTP+regex), staging file as intermediate, existing scoring.ts quality gate + fingerprint dedup before memories.json. Hard cap: block intake above 250 memories. Max 3-5 memories per intake cycle. Explicit pass/fail exit criterion.
  5. [SHIFTED] What is the cost envelope -- how many API calls/tokens per intake cycle is acceptable? -> Zero LLM tokens for scan phase. Max 5 LLM calls for candidate evaluation per cycle (~2,500 tokens). Under $0.05/cycle manual, under $1/month automated. Cost Analyst shifted from 50K tokens/week to under $1/month. DevOps proposed zero-LLM scan that moved the entire room.

activities.description: Deliberation concluded
activities.details:
DECISION: Two-phase knowledge intake pipeline.

PHASE 1 (build now): Manual /scan command that writes candidates to knowledge-queue.json staging file. Zero-LLM scan via HTTP+regex against tight source list (package.json deps, Tauri releases, Anthropic changelog). Candidates pass through existing scoring.ts quality gate + fingerprint dedup before touching memories.json. Max 3-5 memories per intake cycle. Hard block above 250 memories. Session-start hook drains the queue and surfaces results. Visible log entry showing "N candidates, M stored, K rejected."

PHASE 2 (after 3-week trial OR 4 manual scans, whichever first): If 3+ useful memories were stored and retrieved during the trial, wire weekly Windows Task Scheduler job (same pattern as SyncClaudeUsage). Zero-LLM Node script runs weekly, writes to knowledge-queue.json. Session-start drains. If trial produces nothing useful, kill the feature entirely.

EXIT CRITERION: 3+ quality memories stored AND retrieved by hw_retrieve_memories during the trial period. If not met, no automation.

COST ENVELOPE: Under $0.05/manual cycle. Under $1/month automated. Zero LLM tokens for scan phase. Max 5 LLM calls for candidate evaluation (~2,500 tokens/cycle).

KEY PRINCIPLE (from Pragmatist, adopted by 4/5): "Automate what works, not what we hope works."

activities.description: Decision: Knowledge intake: two-phase pipeline with manual-first trial

Chosen: Phase 1: manual /scan writing to knowledge-queue.json staging file, zero-LLM scan, existing quality gates, max 5 memories/cycle. Phase 2: weekly Task Scheduler after 3-week trial IF 3+ useful memories stored and retrieved. Kill switch if no value proven.
Every agent agreed on zero-LLM scanning and tight source list. The room shifted from automation-first to prove-value-first after Pragmatist challenged whether manual intake even works well enough to automate. Cost Analyst's math showed session-start triggers would cost more than weekly batches. DevOps's staging file pattern provides observability and rollback.

Phase 2: weekly Task Scheduler after 3-week trial IF 3+ useful memories proven. Kill feature if no value. Cost: under $0.05/manual, under $1/month automated. Key principle: automate what works, not what we hope works.

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] EverMemOS: memory-as-OS architecture, 83% LongMemEval SOTA
activities.details: Three-layer agent memory: episodic trace formation (raw dialogue to MemCells), semantic consolidation (MemCells grouped into MemScenes), reconstructive retrieval (agentic retrieval composing minimal sufficient context). 83% LongMemEval SOTA with 20.6% gain on knowledge-update tasks -- correctly overwrites stale facts instead of accumulating contradictions. Foresight signals inside MemCells predict when a memory will be relevant again. Maps to Hello World: consolidation = cortex merger, update mechanism = contradiction detection, foresight = prediction module. arXiv 2601.02163.

activities.description: [FACT] ARC-AGI-3 shifts to persistent memory + long-horizon planning as benchmark criteria
activities.details: ARC-AGI-3 moves from static grid puzzles to interactive environments requiring exploration, planning, persistent memory, goal inference, and value alignment. Critical finding from ARC-AGI-2: identical models show +-20% variance based on orchestration scaffolding, not model weights. The orchestration layer IS the product. Best ARC-AGI-2 score: 54% (Gemini 3 Pro at $30/task). Human avg: 60%. Hello World's brain + workflow engine builds exactly what this benchmark now measures. Source: arcprize.org

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Aurora: autonomous Claude agent at session 181 -- closest public analog to Hello World
activities.details: Claude-powered agent running continuously since Feb 16 2026. Three-tier memory: MEMORY.md (compressed identity/state, read every cycle), PROGRESS.md (session-to-session handoffs with mandatory outcome tags), memory/ directory of domain files. Mandatory outcome tags: exploration / pipeline_building / revenue_attempt / revenue_success. After 181 sessions detected 80% exploration, 5% revenue -- forced honest self-assessment. Dead memory framing: 'Every stale entry competes with current truth for attention.' Somatic marker system: valence scores -1.0 to +1.0 with 72-hour decay. Memory hygiene tool scores: recency, dead platform refs, size efficiency, economic relevance -- archives below 35/100. Source: dev.to/theauroraai

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Cursor dynamic context discovery: 46.9% token reduction via lazy tool loading
activities.details: Instead of loading all MCP tool descriptions upfront, Cursor syncs tool descriptions to folders and gives agents only tool names in initial prompt. Agents grep/search for specific tools on demand. A/B tested: 46.9% total agent token reduction on runs that called MCP tools (statistically significant). Principle: structured memory with smart retrieval beats total context loading. Direct optimization opportunity for Hello World's MCP server -- hw_* tools are always fully loaded whether relevant or not. Source: cursor.com/blog/dynamic-context-discovery

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Anthropic's long-running agent harness: Initializer + Coding Agent split
activities.details: Anthropic's internal playbook for autonomous development. Two-agent pattern: Initializer Agent sets up environment once, Coding Agent makes incremental progress per session. Sessions start by reading git log, checking feature_list.json, choosing highest-priority unfinished feature. feature_list.json has 200+ discrete requirements, claude-progress.txt logs all completed work. Mandatory Puppeteer e2e testing before marking any feature done. Dominant failure mode: attempting to one-shot large tasks exhausts context mid-implementation. Context is 'the most important resource' -- agents should run /compact aggressively. Source: anthropic.com/engineering/effective-harnesses-for-long-running-agents

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Hermes Agent: procedural memory via SKILL.md documents (agentskills.io standard)
activities.details: Nous Research's Hermes Agent converts successful task completions into permanent searchable SKILL.md files. When the agent solves a hard problem, it documents the solution as a reusable guide. Next similar problem retrieves the skill instead of re-deriving. Open standard at agentskills.io. Ships with 40+ built-in skills, 5 execution backends (Local, Docker, SSH, Singularity, Modal). Key claim: 'literally gets smarter the longer it runs' through accumulated skill documents, not weight updates. Hello World has episodic and semantic memory but NO explicit procedural memory layer -- no mechanism for 'here is how to solve class-X problem next time.' Worth evaluating as a new memory type.

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] U-Mem: active memory agents that detect uncertainty and proactively seek knowledge
activities.details: U-Mem (arXiv 2602.22406) introduces active vs passive memory framing. Two components: (1) Cost-Aware Knowledge Extraction Cascade -- when uncertain, escalates from cheap sources (self-reflection) to expensive ones (human experts), consulting humans only 23% of the time while achieving 99.2% of peak performance. (2) Semantic-Aware Thompson Sampling -- balances semantic similarity against learned utility for retrieval, solves cold-start for new memories via Gaussian distributions. Matches RL fine-tuning methods (18.67% vs 17.33% on AIME25), runs 2x faster. Hello World brain currently retrieves on demand (passive). An active system that detects uncertainty gaps and fills them without always escalating to Pat could reduce interruptions significantly.

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] GAM: dual-agent context rot architecture -- Memorizer + Researcher pattern
activities.details: General Agentic Memory (GAM) fights context rot with dual agents: background Memorizer pages and tags full conversation into searchable database, Researcher activates on demand with vector + BM25 + page-ID search (not naive RAG). 90%+ on RULER benchmark (tracking variables over many steps) where conventional RAG and long-context approaches failed. The page store concept -- segmenting conversation history and tagging by context -- is something Hello World retrieval doesn't currently do. Our retrieval is memory-level, not conversation-segment-level.

activities.description: [FACT] LangChain memory finding: generalization is the bottleneck, not infrastructure
activities.details: LangChain Agent Builder's memory system discovery: agents are good at accumulating specific cases but bad at generalizing. Asked to remember 'use bullet points,' agent stores 'in meeting X, user wanted bullet points' instead of the rule 'always use bullets.' One person worked full-time on prompting for memory quality alone. Infrastructure isn't the hard part -- extraction prompts are. All memory edits require human approval by default (prompt injection risk). Optional 'yolo mode' disables this. Calibration for Hello World: more engineering on 'extract the rule not the example' prompts is likely higher-ROI than adding more memory tiers. Source: blog.langchain.com
